scenes.text: Cats have five toes on their front paws, and four on their back paws.
A group of cats is called a clowder.
Adult cats typically sleep 12–16 hours each day.
Cats can rotate their ears up to 180 degrees to pinpoint sounds.
Cats have five toes on their front paws, and four on their back paws.
A group of cats is called a clowder.
Adult cats typically sleep 12–16 hours each day.
Cats can rotate their ears up to 180 degrees to pinpoint sounds.
A cat's nose has a unique pattern, similar to a human fingerprint.
Domestic cats descend from the Near Eastern wildcat.
Cats groom themselves to regulate temperature and reduce scent.
Whiskers help cats sense nearby objects and subtle air movements.
Cats can make over 100 different vocal sounds, while dogs make about 10.
Purring may have healing properties and can support tissue recovery.
Most cats cannot taste sweets because they lack the necessary taste receptors.
Cats often land on their feet thanks to a flexible spine and righting reflex.
A cat's heart rate is faster than a human's, typically 140–220 beats per minute.
Kittens usually open their eyes between 7 and 10 days after birth.
Many cats are crepuscular — most active at dawn and dusk.
Cats primarily sweat through the pads of their paws.
A male cat is often called a tom, while a female is called a queen.
The oldest recorded cat lived to be 38 years old.
Cats have a free-floating clavicle that helps them squeeze through tight spaces.
In some cultures, black cats are considered good luck.
A cat's brain is structurally similar to a human brain, about 90% in common.
Cats use scent marking from glands to communicate territory and identity.
The Maine Coon is one of the largest domestic cat breeds.
The Singapura is among the smallest recognized domestic cat breeds.
Cats can jump up to six times their body length in a single leap.
When a cat yawns it may be stretching facial muscles or signaling relaxation.
Cats have a reflective layer behind their retina called the tapetum lucidum for night vision.
A cat's whiskers are roughly as wide as its body and help judge openings.
Many cats enjoy water and can swim, though preferences vary by individual.
A cat's tail position is an important indicator of mood and intention.
Cats have extra vertebrae in their spine, giving them great flexibility.
Polydactyl cats have extra toes and were historically valued by sailors.
Cats can sprint at speeds up to about 30 mph (48 km/h) in short bursts.
The first cloned pet was a cat nicknamed CC (CopyCat).
Indoor cats often live longer than outdoor cats due to fewer hazards.
Cats sometimes bring 'gifts' like prey to their owners as part of hunting behavior.
On average, cats spend about two-thirds of their lives sleeping.
Slow blinking from a cat is often a sign of trust and affection.
Whiskers also help cats measure whether they can fit through openings.
A cat's milk is tailored to kittens and is not ideal for adult humans.
Breeds like the Sphynx have little hair due to genetic mutations.
A cat's sense of smell is far more acute than a human's, about 14 times stronger.
Ancient Egyptians revered cats and often depicted them in art and sculpture.
Some cats can develop separation anxiety if left alone frequently.
Female cats can have kittens in a single litter with multiple fathers.
Cats have scent glands on their cheeks which they use to mark familiar people and places.
